hawaiian_text: Noho ihola i laila, mahi ‘ai, ‘elua āna mau māla  ‘uala lō‘ihi e waiho nei ā hiki i kēia lā, a ua kapa ‘ia  ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i  kēia lā. A o‘o ka ‘uala, ‘ōlelo ‘o Puali‘i i kāna ‘ōlelo   ho‘ohiki, “Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala,  a ‘ai ‘o Puali‘i, a laila, noa, ‘ai kāna wahine, Pōka‘ī a  me nā mea ‘ē a‘e. No laila, iho akula ‘o Puali‘i i kai  o Honouliuli e lawai‘a i i‘a ‘ai pū me ka ‘uala.
deepseek-v3-0324-fireworks_translation: They stayed there, cultivating crops. There were two of his long sweet potato fields that remain to this day, and the name of these fields is called Nāmakaokapāo'o to this very day. When the sweet potatoes matured, Puali'i made his solemn vow: "When the head of the ulua fish is baked with the sweet potatoes, and Puali'i eats, then the restriction is lifted, and his woman Pōka'ī and the others may eat." Therefore, Puali'i went down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for fish to eat together with the sweet potatoes.
deepseek-v3-0324-fireworks_commentary:
**Paragraph 4:**
• This passage reveals several key elements of traditional Hawaiian agricultural practices and kapu (sacred prohibition) systems:
   – The reference to "two long sweet potato fields" (ʻelua mau māla ʻuala lōʻihi) carries potential numerological significance, as pairs often represent balance in Hawaiian thought (cf. Kāne-Kanaloa dualism in creation stories).
   – The naming of agricultural fields after individuals (ʻo Nāmakaokapāoʻo) reflects the Hawaiian concept of imbuing land with personal and ancestral mana - a practice documented in the 1880 Hawaiian Government Survey notes where patches were named after notable growers.

• The sacred meal protocol described shows strict ʻAi Kapu gender restrictions:
   – Pualiʻi's vow follows the classic structure of kapu-lifting rituals: a) sacred preparation (kālua cooking), b) sequential consumption (male first), c) declaration of noa (ʻfree from restrictionʼ).
   – The pairing of ulua head (poʻo o ka ulua) with ʻuala carries deep symbolism:
       * Ulua fish represented masculinity and chiefly status (as seen in ʻŌlelo Noʻeau 2932)
       * The ʻuala (sweet potato) was a female-associated crop (contrast with male-associated taro)
       * This forms a gender-complementary ritual meal, similar to ceremonial pairings at luakini temples

• The geographic movement patterns reflect traditional resource procurement:
   – Pualiʻi's journey from upland fields (where ʻuala grows best) to marine areas (Honouliuli) exemplifies the ahupuaʻa system of vertical resource access
   – The specific mention of Honouliuli (dark bay) in ʻEwa district connects to historical fishing grounds documented in Kepelino's Traditions of Hawaiʻi

• The passage preserves intact several linguistic features of late 18th century Oʻahu dialect:
   – Use of lōʻihi for "long" rather than lōa (more common today)
   – Retention of the causative hoʻohiki (to vow) showing classical verb morphology
   – The ritualized speech formula "Aia ā...a laila" follows patterns recorded in Malo's Hawaiian Antiquities Chapter 30

• Allegorical interpretations suggest this may encode agricultural cycles:
   – The two fields could represent wet/dry cultivation methods
   – The ulua-ʻuala pairing mirrors the makahiki cycle where ocean yields (fish) follow land yields (crops)
   – The kapu release after Pualiʻi eats may symbolize the opening of ʻuala harvest season

• The perpetuation of the name Nāmakaokapāoʻo to present day reflects:
   – The Hawaiian concept of pīʻāpā naming (binding names to places through use)
   – A possible reference to eye-shaped sweet potato tubers (maka=eyes, pāoʻo=fish) creating visual wordplay
   – The endurance of oral history in place names as noted in Kamakau's Tales and Traditions

reference_translation: They lived there and farmed, and Puali‘i had two  long sweet potato patches that remain until today,  and the patches were given the name,   Nāmakaokapāo‘o until today. When the sweet  potatoes were mature, Puali‘i said made a  promise, saying, “I’ll cook the head of an ulua fish  in the imu along with some sweet potatoes. When  Puali‘i eats, then the food will be made free for his  woman, Pōka‘ī, and anyone else.” So, Puali‘i went  down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for a catch  to eat with sweet potatoes.
